posts.name: Jose Laureano
posts.cooked: At the Orlando Regional, our pit neighbors, team 5816, had an interesting suction cup based manipulator. Unfortunately, it never saw action outside of the pit and the team resorted to just playing defense. What other unique systems have you come across, both in this season, and other past seasons?

posts.name: Kaitlyn
posts.cooked: At the Miami Valley Regional team 544 had a catapult-type mechanism that flipped the cone onto nodes.  It may not have been the most efficient, but it was definitely the coolest to watch.

posts.name: Evan Kruger
posts.cooked:
Team 3459 in North Carolina built a passive ground intake that handed off to an over the top grabber. It didnâ€™t work great from what I saw, but it stood out from all the other grabbers Iâ€™ve seen.

posts.name: Evan Kruger
posts.cooked: There is no team 544. There was a 554 at that event though, are you referring to them by any chance?

posts.name: Ian McTavish
posts.cooked:
Screenshot_20230323-175816 677Ã—669 29.2 KB PXL_20230303_214823955 1920Ã—1440 360 KB We won the creativity award at Georgian College for our stinger. Instead of rack and pinion we drilled holes and use a sprocket. Works very smoothly.

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
Ian_McTavish:

Instead of rack and pinion

3468 did this as well.

I donâ€™t recall who, but someone at Magnolia had a rack and pinion using a sprocket for a pinion and for a rack, they managed to slide some 25 chain down into the groove of a 90-20 style extrusion.  I could see at a glance that it had to go up and down because of the cable runs to allow for it, but it took me a few seconds to find the actual engagement.

I"ve definitely seen more R&P type systems (some using belt secured to a piece of extrusion with a sheave as well as those above and traditional gearing) this year than I ever have before.

posts.name: Kaitlyn
posts.cooked: Yes that is what I meant to type.  Whoops!
